content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'm learning python,
This Clash seems very simple at first glance but there are lots of little subtleties during the tests which make it very interesting and less simple,
I liked it, well done

In the Goal section please format bananas as a variable when needed.
Your input section dosen't correspond to your stub generator. what is n_monkeys ? the variable name is monkeys. Same you can better name x in the output section

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Beyond the criteria mentioned, this contribution offers significant educational value. It challenges participants to apply important programming concepts and problem-solving strategies, such as sorting, greedy algorithms, and efficient data manipulation. This makes the contribution not just a test of skill but also a learning opportunity, reinforcing key concepts in a practical and engaging way.

In summary, accepting this contribution is justified because it meets essential quality criteria—clarity, well-defined test cases, and appropriate difficulty level—while also offering educational value to participants. It strikes a balance between challenging and accessible, making it a valuable addition to any collection of coding challenges or puzzles.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash, easy but not too easy.

Overall, it's fun.

Suggestions:
1- Include a test case for 0 bananas.
2- Clarify Line 2 further.
3- Use space-separated integers instead of comma-separated ones.

Good Luck.
Suggestion: Add some harder test cases (We're staying at low ends of constraints with only one number greater than 10.)

Constraints
* "bananas" is not defined anywhere else in the statement. Does it refer to "n" in Line 1? If so, please change either variable name so that the names are consistent. (Preferably bananas, because that's also used in the stub generator.)

* Please change "[[len(monkeys)]]" to "length([[monkeys]])".

Better still, please add "[[n_monkeys]]" in front of "comma separated integers" in Line 2, and then change "[[len(monkeys)]]" to "[[n_monkeys]]".

* Please change "[[monkeys[i]]]" to "[[i]]" as that is used in Line 2 (i is not used as an index there).

Cases
* Test 4: Please revise the case to require output of 0, similar to Validator 4.

Thanks.
I implemented your suggested improvements. Thanks for the thoughts and ideas!
I now added some more test cases with higher numbers which are close to the upper end. Thanks for the suggestion!
I implemented your recommended changes. Thanks for the recommendations.
